noun.description: An act of hitting or striking someone or something; a blow.
examples: he received three strokes of the cane

noun.description: A mark made by drawing a pen, pencil, or paintbrush in one direction across paper or canvas.
examples: the paint had been applied in careful, regular strokes

noun.description: An act of moving one's hand across a surface with gentle pressure.
examples: massage the cream into your skin using light upward strokes

noun.description: A movement, especially one of a series, in which something moves out of its position and back into it; a beat.
examples: the ray swam with effortless strokes of its huge wings

noun.description: A sudden disabling attack or loss of consciousness caused by an interruption in the flow of blood to the brain, especially through thrombosis.

verb.description: Move one's hand with gentle pressure over (a surface, especially hair, fur, or skin), typically repeatedly; caress.
examples: he put his hand on her hair and stroked it

verb.description: Act as the stroke of (a boat or crew)
examples: he stroked Penn's rowing eight to victory

verb.description: Hit or kick (a ball) smoothly and deliberately.
examples: Miller calmly stroked three-pointers throughout the tournament

phrases: attitudes cannot be changed at one stroke
This more than doubled Artemis's size at a stroke, as well as giving it a much stronger marketing platform on which to build.
Local residents have been stunned by the plans, which would double the size of the local population at a stroke.
It was, in truth, a compromise, and the working arrangement suddenly threatens to come crashing down at a stroke.
That would do it, world peace at one stroke of the cheque book.
origin: Old English strācian caress lightly, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch streek a stroke, German streichen to stroke, also to strike. The earliest noun sense blow is first recorded in Middle English.
